fields.description: As part of ELB benchmarks, I ran 'ab' command line to generate lots of HTTP traffic to instances. At around 30K'th HTTP GET, the instance starts to freeze. After more debugging, it appears that it has to do with CC's 'nf_conn_track' parameters in kernel. dmesg has "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet". raising the nf_conntrack_max and reducing 'ip_conntrack_generic_timeout' appears to help, but the conclusion is not decisive.
fields.summary: lots of HTTP connection leaves CC in funny state

comments.body: After restarting CC, the symptom disappears (guess we restart iptable)
Dima, please work closely with Sang-min
[~spark] [~tony] this appears to not be a CC issue, if it does please re-assign.
[~spark] has commented on email thread with status: "yes, it's still unresolved. Chris and Dan have engaged and gave us some data. I'll debug it further to figure out the root cause and resolve."
The root cause of this issue (NF_CONN_TRACK parameters) is identified, and the issue will be resolved by changing the kernel config parameters.

These are added lines to /etc/sysctl.conf. Note that these kernel params should be applied to both CC and NC, where iptable runs. 

net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max = 1048576   # 16x of default

#net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_buckets = 262144   # permission error and google suggests that changing the value will pack the kernel

net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_generic_timeout = 120  # previously 600 (10min). so the connection state persisted for 10 min!

net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_tcp_timeout_established = 54000  # from http://pc-freak.net/blog/resolving-nf_conntrack-table-full-dropping-packet-flood-message-in-dmesg-linux-kernel-log/
[~awithrow], please create a doc ticket and link
I recommend handling this in a fashion similar to which the postgres kernel params are handled.  See {{eucalyptus/clc/modules/postgresql/conf/init.d/01_pg_kernel_params}}.
[~mspaulding], please make the changes in the init script for this.  Talk to Sang-Min if you need any clarification
[~mspaulding], note that [~shashi] may tweak the final values based on customer input.  But go ahead and put the mechanism in.
[~shashi][~mspaulding] I don't think this is something customers need to know about. we should find the best value (the value above is ok, but we may find the better later) and fix.

[~spark], Agreed that this is a good place to start for 3.3. We will have more feedback coming in between 3.3.0 and 3.3.1 and we could perhaps use more concrete numbers from the field then. Current POCs numbers may not be indicative of the production load. For 3.3, let's proceed with the current tests and publish "tested" maximum concurrent and total connections, and any other metric that you think will be useful for our users to know / help plan their deployment. Thanks.

Could be a documentation task hence cc'ing [~smarvin].
[~mspaulding] [~nurmi] is iptables NAT possible without conntrack? hmm..

Ah, yeah, I think you're right [~spark]. It looks like if we try to prevent the nf_conntrack modules from loading (via modprobe blacklist at least) NAT will not function.

Since, from what I understand, this only affects the CC and NC then I'll go ahead and add the settings you've specified to the eucalyptus-cc(-nc) packages.

[~decker], I'm not sure if I agree that these values should be applied using the same method as with postgresql. Since these need to be applied for the CC and NC, there is not necessarily a /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d/ directory, and I think putting a script in say, /etc/eucalyptus/ would be inconsistent.

I'll put the kernel parameter script in /usr/libexec/eucalyptus/ which is more standard. The eucalyptus-cc and eucalyptus-nc init scripts will call the parameter script when starting their services.
reverted the state as we found multiple kernel panics that appears to be related to this change.
[~mspaulding] do we change the parameters in source build? the panicked machines were source build..
Yes, kernel parameters should be applied any time the init script for the CC or NC is called. If I can get access to the system or logs I might be able to verify if that was the case for sure.
I've been running stress test. So far a cloud could sustain for about 16 hours of continuous http traffic generated from ab. I'll setup a few more qa clouds and run similar stress tests.

I've been running stress tests on two clouds each with multi-zone.
Two loadbalancers were used to test two CCs in each cloud. 'ab' continuously generates traffic from backend  apache. Both clouds are running ok for the last 24 hours. I'll keep them running over the weekend and if it doesn't break will mark this release pending.

That's great news!

--
Tony
On May 10, 2013 3:09 PM, "Sang-Min Park (JIRA)" <
The stress test was successful for the weekend (3 days). I'll move this to release pending.
Resolved in the 3.3.0 release
